items.description: North Sea coast from Whitby to Filey

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message:
This flood alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast this evening between 5 PM and 8 PM on 13/03/2023.
Areas most at risk include the North Sea coast from Whitby to Filey, particularly in the Scarborough Foreshore Road and Sandside area. 
After this tideâ€š the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected. We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 9 PM on 13/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively monitoring river levels and the weather forecast.
Please avoid contact with any standing flood water which may remain.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels are rising and forecast to continue rising at the Torksey river gauge as a result of snowmelt and rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 23:00 tonight, 13/03/2023.  Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point, and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. However, further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  We expect river levels to remain high beyond 14/03/2023.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our field team staff are closing pointing doors at Torksey today, around 12:00, 13/03/2023.
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 21:20 this evening, 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Warwick river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall overnight and into Monday morning.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Avon between Rugby and Bidford including Warwick, Stratford upon Avon, caravan parks and farmland.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high throughout Monday 13/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 17.00 on 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are falling at the Dernford river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing. Flooding is affecting River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach.

Further rain is forecast for the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

This message will be updated this afternoon, 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding continues.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 17:00 this afternoon, 13/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen on the River Lune; River Conder due to steady rainfall overnight and during Monday morning.
Flooding is possible at River Lune, Conder and Keer and other watercourses from Kirkby Lonsdale to Galgate including Gressingham, Carnforth, Hornby, Wray, Bentham and Lancaster from 2pm on 13/03/2023.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout the afternoon and into this evening.
River levels are expected to remain high at the Caton; Galgate gauge for the rest of the day.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 09:30 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River levels are rising on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water due to heavy rainfall overnight.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.
No property flooding is expected.
River levels are expected to remain high for the rest of today, Monday 13th March.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising on the Rivers Kent and Bela due to heavy rainfall overnight.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Rivers Kent and Bela, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Rivers Kent and Bela and other watercourses, from Kentmere to Silverdale including low lying areas around Staveley, Burneside, Kendal, Milnthorpe and Beetham.
No property flooding is expected.
River levels are expected to remain high for the rest of today, Monday 13th March.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Erewash in Derbyshire and Nottinghamshire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are rising on the River Cherwell as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and farmland is expected, especially in the Thrupp area. 
The forecast today is for outbreaks of rain which may turn heavy at times. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area clearing weed/trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the River Wey as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of footpaths and farmland is possible over today 13/03/23, especially in the Godalming and Bordon areas. Levels started to rise yesterday evening after a period of heavy rainfall and are expected to continue to respond to rainfall over today particularly on the Hell Ditch. 
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over today. We expect river levels to rise over the next day.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of snowmelt and rainfall. Consequently, flooding is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. Predicted peaks:- Llanymynech 4.4m to 4.9m Tuesday morning, 14/03/2023. Further rainfall is expected today, 13/03/2023. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses & plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded . This message will be updated by 14:00 on 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Titley Mill river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Arrow from Michaelchurch to Brierley. Other areas that may be affected include Kington, Staunton and Eardisland.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next week.   We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 18:00 on 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land & roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge & Bridgnorth. River Severn  bankfull at White Abbey. Predicted Peaks:- Crew Green 6.1m to 6.5m tomorrow afternoon 14/03/23, Montford 6m to 6.4m 15/03/23, Welshbridge 4m to 4.4m 15/03/23, Buildwas 5.3m to 5.7m 15/03/23, Bridgnorth 4.2m to 4.7m 16/03/23.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next week.  We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.

Please note that although this flood alert is no longer in force, we are are continuing to monitor rainfall and river levels.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the River Ray as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and farmland is possible, especially in the Lower Arncott and Islip areas. 
The forecast today is for outbreaks of rain which may turn heavy at times. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area clearing weed/trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Hay-On-Wye river gauge as a result of recent rainfall & snowmelt. Consequently, flooding of roads & farmland is expected to begin this morning, 13/03/23. We expect flooding to affect low lying land & roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Other locations that may be affected include the A438, Byford, Bredwardine & Hereford. Predicted peaks:- Hay on Wye 2.4m to 2.9m this evening 13/03/23, Bredwardine 4.4m to 4.9m  14/03/23, Belmont 4.5m to 5.0m 14/03/23, Old Wye Bridge 3.8m to 4.3m 14/03/23, Mordiford 4.3m to 4.7m 14/03/23, Ross on Wye 3.1m to 3.6m 15/03/23. Further rainfall is forecast today, 13/03/23. We expect river levels to remain high for the next 5 days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses & plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 14:00 on 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Cambridgeshire, North Northamptonshire, Peterborough, West Northamptonshire

items.message: River Nene levels have remained high since the heavy rainfall and snow last week, which has led to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. Although river levels have receded, there is further rainfall forecast for today, 13th March 2023, and the next few days. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outbuildings is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 19:00 on 13/03/23, or before if the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the River Thame and Chalgrove Brook as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and farmland is possible, especially in the Stadhampton and Dorchester areas. 
The forecast today is for outbreaks of rain which may turn heavy at times. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area clearing weed/trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated his evening 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
River levels are high but steady on the River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle due to rainfall.
Areas most at risk include the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole.. No property flooding is expected.
Flooding is possible at the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. from 12:00 noon on 13/03/2023.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout the afternoon and the river level may rise in response to the rain, so the risk of flooding to roads remains.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
      
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Sutton Gault, Earith and Welney river gauges as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today, Monday 13 March and is likely to continue for the first half of the week. 

Flooding is affecting Hundred Foot Washes, also known as the Ouse Washes, including the causeways at Earith, Sutton Gault and Welney.

This information is correct as of 07:00 on Monday 13 March. The Welney causeway currently has 8 cm of water on the road. Earith has approximately 10 cm of water on the road and the causeway at Sutton Gault has 45 cm of water on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways and Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the roads
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated again before this afternoon, 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Shardlow and Willington river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until at least Thursday, 16/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 17:00 this afternoon, 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels are high but steady on Sunday the 12th March 2022 at the Bradford on Avon river gauge as a result of the recent heavy rainfall. We expect the River Avon to remain high for the next coming days; its possible there will be some flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.   

The weather forecast for late Sunday and into Monday suggests some large rainfall totals. We will continue to closely monitor the situation.   

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  This message will be updated on the 13 March 2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Hookagate river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Shrewsbury to Church Stretton. Other locations that may be affected include Minsterley, Pontesford and Harrington. The floodplain has started to fill adjacent to the gauge on the left bank.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next week.   We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 18:00 on 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.    
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

This alert remains in force due to raised levels on the River Ure following snowmelt and overnight rainfall on Sunday 12th March 2023. The areas most at risk are low lying roads, paths and farmland near watercourses. Flooding of areas near Low Houses and Bainbridge is possible throughout Monday 13th March 2023. Please exercise caution around low lying areas and put any relevant flood plans into action. We will continue to monitor the forecast and river levels and will update this message by 16:00 on Monday afternoon or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Cambridgeshire from Brampton to Earith
items.message:
River levels are high and holding steady at the Offord river gauge. River levels are slowly falling at the St Ives river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding is affecting River Great Ouse from Brampton to Earith, including Back Brook, Hall Green Brook, Parsons Drove Drain, Swavesey Drain and Wadsbys Folly.
Further rain is forecast for the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated this afternoon, 13/03/23, or as the situation changes.

Further rain is forecast for the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: River Nene river levels have remained high since the heavy rain and snow last week. Further rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours and more in the following days. During periods of high tide the River Nene will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding of the North Bank Road, between Peterborough and Rings End. Whilst this Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. We are operating the Whittlesey washlands to help manage the situation. This Flood Warning is expected to remain in place until at least Tuesday 14th March 2023, whilst river and tide levels remain high. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 19:00 on 13/03/23, or before, if the situation changes.

items.description: The River Stour from Sudbury to Stratford St Mary and Dedham
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Monday 13 March. River levels are currently high, but are expected to start to drop back down to more normal levels later today. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas of the River Stour between Sudbury and Dedham. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for further unsettled weather through the week. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 5pm Monday 13 March or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Colne from Great Yeldham to Colchester
items.message: River levels are now returning to normal. The forecast is for further unsettled weather throughout the week. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

River Nene levels have remained high since the heavy rainfall and snow last week, which has led to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. Further rainfall forecast for today, 13th March 2023, and the next few days will keep the river levels high. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outbuildings is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. We are operating to the Whittlesey Washlands to help manage the situation. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 19:00 on 13/03/23, or before if the situation changes.

Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.

items.message:
River levels have risen overnight on the Upper Tees due to a combination of snow melt and heavy rain and will remain above normal today, 13/03/2023 with further spells of heavy rain expected today, 13/03/2023. Areas most at risk are riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
No flood warnings are anticipated. 

This message will be updated by 17:00 today, 13/03/2023.

River levels have risen at the Coleshill river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today Monday 13/03/23. 
Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Cole between Majors Green and Coleshill.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
